description.text: I used a servo that I had laying around that was modified for continuous rotation to motorize the gear heart. It works of 6v dc.

This is a work in progress. I plan on designing a better base and servo mount and printing them.
  • I drilled the hole in the base all they way through the bottom.
  • I then glued a 1/4" diameter rod to the heart center and ran it through the heart base.
  • I glued the heart base to the heart stand and glued the heart stand to a piece of wood. Which I had already drilled a hole in for the drive rod.
  • I attached a gear to the drive rod that matched the gear on that I had on the servo.
  • Mounted the servo to the piece of wood, making sure to match up the gears for smooth rotation.
  • Added power and watched it spin. I need make the speed variable.
    • I'm thinking of making a hand-crank version as well.

comments.text: Looks pretty cool, but it sounds like you've got some pretty serious gear slippage going on! That could however be fixed by lowering the speed and letting it wear in for a while.
comments.author: Zh4x0r

description.text:
I have some of these listed in My Things that are .4mm thick which work fine for small oscillations but aren't quite enough for a quad that is more prone to vibrations getting from the motors to the flight controller. These are 1.4mm thick and should be printed with 2 solid top and bottom layers and a 30-40% infill for more cushioning. I've included a video showing the difference it made for me with my Armattan Chameleon having rough motors at mid throttle.

https://youtu.be/D3y9QM8lTPo

I designed this desk a few years ago. I needed a new electronics workbench with overhead lighting and a shelf for my equipment. Our local Fab-Lab was running a design contest for furniture in which this desk ended third.
This design is a flat pack desk that only requires a hammer (and a file) to assemble, no screws or glue is needed. In the first iteration I used long pieces of MDF to support the large work area. This was insufficient so I replaced them with generic wooden beams from the local DIY store.
My initial thoughts went to a TL tube for lighting, but I came across some high brightness led strips at a low price which I glued on a aluminum U-profile and stuck to the desk.

title: Thinkgeek Mighty Atom RC Helicopter Fix

description.text:
A weight on the stabilizer on my super-cheap, mini-RC-helicopter flew off and disappeared. 
I would seem it's a common problem and replacement parts are impossible to find. 
Thing-o-matic to the rescue!

You will need:
  • 2 x M3 nut
  • Acetone
  • Acetone Applicator
  • Print two of the little things.
  • Screw a standard M3 nut onto the narrow end of the each thing.
  • Put the thing onto the stabilizer where the weight was (nut end first).
  • Using an appropriate applicator, get some acetone up in there to weld the thing to the stabilizer rod.
  • Wait for the weld to dry.
    • Note: I didn't try but I doubt this would work if you only replaced one - best to remove the other weight if only one detached.

title: Anycubic prusa i3 functional Z-Top-Mount Hex and more

description.text:
I reworked the Z-top Mount for the Anycubic Prusa i3 and added some 13mm+0.2mm Hex holes to it, so some custom addons can be used, like a filament guide or a tool holder.
It fits tight, so also the Z-Axis steel rod, unlike with the Acrylic one.
I might add some more Addons for my design.

If you want to add some addons/tools, they fit nicely with an exact 13mm Hex.

If you have printed one i would really appreciate a "i made one" - post :)

You can find the Spool Holder, without the rest, here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2097338
And the clamps:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2190187

Edit: Added an improved filament guide. Its stronger, looks better and guides better.
Edit2: Added an other tool holder, so you can have all tools, that came with the printer on your printer. Also added some clamps for fixing the frame on a wooden plate. ̶p̶̶i̶̶c̶̶t̶̶u̶̶r̶̶e̶̶s̶̶ ̶̶w̶̶i̶̶l̶̶l̶̶ ̶̶f̶̶o̶̶l̶̶l̶̶o̶̶w̶̶.̶

Anycubic Prusa i3

No

No

0.3mm

15%

Printed with ABS and some small warping issues, but PLA should work fine too.

filament_holder_right_mirror_for_left.stl is the version for the right side, for left side just mirror it. I also recommend to mirror z-top-mount_with_hex_holes for the left side, so you have the same surface on both sides (if you print it on both sides).

title: Ikea Dresser Drawer Dog Bed Retrofit

description.text: Convert an Ikea dresser drawer into a stylish dog bed!

In addition to the drawer and hardware included you will need: 6x M3x8mm machine screws
Woodworking tools capable of a rip cut and a curve.
Metric tap and dye set
Hand drill w/ 1/8" all purpose drill bit.
Sandpaper: 80-120, 150 grit
2x nails or pins
1x length of cord or string, twice as long as your longest board just to be safe
1x Pencil, sharpened
Eye protection for all participants
Ear protection for all participants
Paint or wood stain, drop cloth, brushes, etc...
  • Remove rails from drawer, retain mounting screws.
  • Disassemble drawer, retain all hardware.
  • Using back panel as a template, rip cut front panel bottom edge such that there remains an equal distance from the edge to the dado in which the floor rests. Course sand ripped surface with 80-120 grit sandpaper.
  • Scribe a half-ellipse on back panel top edge. I find the gardeners ellipse to be expedient and precise. The equation you want is
    f^2 = a^2 - b^2
    where a = semi-major axis, b = semi-minor axis, and f = linear eccentricity, in other words the distance from the origin to each of the foci.
  • Cut out the half-ellipse using a jig saw or similar method. Course sand cut surface with 80-120 grit sandpaper.
  • Reassemble all but the floor using retained hardware. Finish sand all surfaces with 150 grit, then 120 grit sandpaper. Stain/paint as desired.
  • Print 4x feet and 6x supports. I used:
    PLA
    .4mm nozzle
    .2mm layer height
    no support
    50% infil
    • For the supports concentric top, bottom, and infil workout out great with every 5th layer solid. The feet were rectilinear top and bottom with honeycomb infil, every 5th layer solid.
  • Clean out screw bores in supports with a small drill bit, then tapped out M3 threads.
    • NOTE: if you do not have a suitable tap and dye set you will want to alter the support design by increasing the radius of the bore to closer match your screws. The STL provided has a 2.5mm diameter bore. Alternately you could simply drill out the bores I suppose.

  • Use the rule of thirds to mark four evenly spaced intersections on drawer floor. Mark two additional points on the short-side centerline about one-third of the way from the edge to the first set of marks (i.e. ~1/9th of the long axis in.) Drill at marks to accomodate screws.

  • Once paint has dried, slide floor into dados, secure with printed feet and screws from rails. Install a support at each drilled hole in floor with M3x8mm screw.

  • Cushion construction beyond the scope of this tutorial, but basically pick fabric, pre-wash and iron, cut two rectangles with edges sized 1/2 the perimeter of respective enclosed plane plus 1/2" for seam. Place outer faces together, straight-stitch 1/4" seam around, leave a gap to invert and stuff. Turn inside out through gap, pack with poly-fill to desired level, pin remaining seam in, whip stitch gap. Check, roger.

title: Proof That Tony Stark Has A Heart

description.text:
"Proof that Tony Stark has a heart"

In the first Iron Man live action movie, Pepper Potts gifts Tony Stark with his old arc reactor, which she turns into a desktop ornament. This iconic movie prop can easily be 3D printed and used as a decorative piece for your desk or nightstand. You can even make it light up with LEDs!

I printed this model at 113% on an Ultimaker 2+ using PLA filament. Depending on the printer and material you use, it may be necessary to scale some parts differently to minimize post processing. For the most part, this model can be put together without glue. You will, however, have to use glue to secure the "Housing" to the "Base". If you choose to add copper wire to the coils, you may have to use glue and do some additional scaling to some parts.

I suggest printing most parts at 113%, however, the "Coil" files (print 10 of these) should be printed around 115% to ensure that they fit around the top ring of the model.

The Arc Reactor can easily be removed from the "Housing" and used as a standalone prop. Also, I modeled a space in the center or the model to make room for LEDs if you choose to add them.

Overall this model is super easy to print! I printed it in a matter of two days, only having to print one part a second time due to a failed print (Ran out of filament). The parts fit together very well if you're careful of your scaling. I did have to do some minor sanding in order to make the "Main" part lock into the "Ring".

I'm super happy with my Arc Reactor prop and I hope that if you choose to print it you are too!

title: Fidget Toy Hand Spinners for 1/2" Ball Bearings

description.text:
No glue needed!

Press the 608 bearing cartridge into the center first - easier to align this way. You want to make sure it is flush on either side. The 608 bearings are the common skateboard bearing size with a 22mm OD

1/2" loose ball bearings press in and snap into center of holes with an audible click. They will rotate in their sockets and not come out. The weight will be balanced when spinning because there is no guess work as to where the center of the hole is.

Buttons have a shoulder for the inner bearing race to ride on so there is no rubbing and you can hold them tightly for fast spins. They are also just wide enough so that the spinner can be spun on a tabletop or hard surface.

The 9 and 10 ball spinners are very heavy. The 6 ball is ideal for one hand spinning and small hands.

comments.text: I've printed several of these on my FDM printer and my sons love them.  I was trying to print one of them on my resin printer and it cracks in half when I try to put the balls in, is there a ready way to convert these into a snap-fit two-piece model so that I can assemble them without cracking my resin prints?
comments.author: RGBAorHex

comments.text: Glad your sons are enjoying the design! Have you tried tinkercad? Even for someone with little to no experience it is pretty easy to import and modify a model. I haven't designed anything for resin yet as I don't have a resin printer. I imagine the tolerances are different they are very different materials, but anyway a snap fit closure would have to be designed or borrowed from something else. And as you are seeing the material is not well suited for being flexible, as in a snap hinge. If you aren't printing with translucent material you could just split in half in tinkercad and glue the pieces - I've done a few poured resin molds this way, splitting a 3d model in half and printing fdm, making 2 silicon molds from halves and then gluing the cast resin pieces together. Alternately you could enlarge the ball holes and glue the balls in. Or even I'm wondering if they have a more flexible resin? Let me know if you find something that works out
comments.author: RGBAorHex

comments.text:
Okay, I was going to try Fusion360. I am printing in a colored transparent resin, so gluing is sort of out, but I'm going to try remixing them with some snap-fit edges as the resin should have just enough flexibility for that before the secondary curing, then it'll cure together into a single piece during the secondary curing. If I can't get it with fusion360, I'll try tinkercad.
Thanks for the feedback, I'll post as a remix if it's successful.

title: Nutcracker cnc/waterjet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
ATTENTION: This thing does not work as good as hoped. Because of the weak point where the front part transition to the handle and the softness of aluminum the construction is not strong enough to crack nuts. I made a improved version with slight modification in the construction and using brass. You can find the Nutcracker II here.

I used the geometry of a wonderful performing nutcracker to create this layered version. The aluminum and oak parts are screwed together. While I used nuts for secure the screws on the handles, I taped threads in the aluminum parts.

This build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 7 mm oak wood using a 2 mm spiral toothed flute and 3 mm aluminum cut with a 2 mm 2-edged flute.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

Keep in mind that the stl-file is for viewing purpose only. It will not work if you print this on a fdm-printer.

Consider a small donation (e.g. 1$) if you like this design. Any amount will help me keeping up with my work.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/kVQV3nmRv1s" ></iframe>

comments.text: You really do awesome work. I just wonder, are you using the kress tool for the aluminum?
comments.author: CharbsJay

comments.text: Not exactly a Kress but a very similar tool.
comments.author: CharbsJay

comments.text: Okay well can you point it out? I am planning on buying the Stepcraft, and I am looking for some opinions about it and what tools seem to work well for soft metals and hard woods. If you can help out it would be nice :)
comments.author: ZenziWerken

comments.text: I use a AW-FSE-500 from CNC-Plus. It's not available at the moment, but you can go with a Kress. It delivers good value for the money and can be used on any Stepcraft-2. Keep in mind that it's a classic aircooled motor that uses conductor brushes ... resulting in high volume (in terms of noise). Further I have to say that a Stepcraft can do metal but it's definitely nothing you would do on a regularly basis. The machine is imho just not strong enough. Another drawback is, that you can't use more than a few drops of liquid coolant. I use methylated spirits which cools when it evaporates.
comments.author: CharbsJay

comments.text: Thank you so much for your tips. Do you think,or know if there is a machine around the same price and is a little stronger, build wise and work wise?
comments.author: ZenziWerken

comments.text:
I suppose these 3040 Chinese machines–you get on eBay–are stronger, BUT you might have other problems in terms of software, support and spare parts. I heard very different judgments. Much the same as for Stepcraft ;) After two years of working with a tiny cnc I would try to build a machine. The principles aren't complicated, but you need to have some precise tools and measuring equipment.
There seems to be a actual gap between a 1000 Euro Stepcraft and something about 3000 Euros for a serious machine.
Don't get me wrong I don't regret buying a Stepcraft. It's worth it's money and get's you an access to the world of cnc. As you can see on my projects: you can do stuff.
comments.author: CharbsJay

comments.text: Yeah I do see your great work and other people's work, the Stepcraft seems to do the job nicely. I was checking Oozenest, and Shapeko, but somehow I still find the Stepcraft to be a better package. I did also check BZT but I thought they were a little overpriced, maybe I don't know much about the details and why its as expensive, but I am still looking and trying to find the right one.

print_settings.Notes:: The bottom printed surface of the lid will be the most-visible part of the final object, so make sure your print platform is nice and clean before you print it! The maximum dimension of the box is about 109 mm, so this will print on most 3D printers. If you rescale (resize) the model the battery clip probably won't work correctly.

description.text:
This is a heart box, designed to be a Valentines Day present or memento. The surprise is a hidden and backlit heart shape in the middle of the lid. Backlighting is provided by a flashing RGB LED powered by a CR2032 battery (which will power the LED for several days and can be easily replaced). No soldering is required -- everything just presses into place and will hold snugly. Whether or not the light is used, the box is big enough to hold goodies if desired (note: the LED is cool and won't melt wrapped chocolate). The box is designed to look good whether or not it is set up on the pedestal.
You can acquire the LEDs and CR2032 at many different places. On Amazon, search for "rgb flashing led 5mm".

Printer:

PolyPrinter 229

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The bottom printed surface of the lid will be the most-visible part of the final object, so make sure your print platform is nice and clean before you print it! The maximum dimension of the box is about 109 mm, so this will print on most 3D printers. If you rescale (resize) the model the battery clip probably won't work correctly.

Here are all the Heart Box components (the battery clip has already been inserted into the box, and battery and LED installed) This closeup shows the battery clip inserted into its mounting bracket in the box (this is a tight fit, but it will go in and stay snug). A CR2032 battery has been inserted into the clip. Bend the LED leads as shown, making sure the positive (longest) lead of the LED contacts the + side of the battery. There are small channels for the LED leads on the interior faces of the battery clip; once you find them the lead will slide across the sides of the battery.

Creating the Circular Text

(Note: this workflow may seem a little long and complex, but it allows me to use relatively-simple techniques with tools that are either free or simple to use to quickly achieve the desired design.)
I like the simple flexibility of Microsoft Office tools for working with text, so I used Word Art to create the circular "I Love You" text in an appealing font. I used the same tools to re-orient the text so the "I" was on the top of the circle, and re-balanced the text to appear more circular (the choice of font made this difficult). I removed all shading variance within the font to prepare for the next steps. I saved the text only as a .PNG picture.
Using Inkscape, I imported the .PNG picture and did a Bitmap Trace to vectorize it. I then saved this in Inkscape's native .SVG format.
I imported this .SVG file into Tinkercad where the final mixing was performed (the heart shape and other detailed designs were created in Sketchup). I gave the lettering object the correct height and converted it into a "hole" object type, and grouped it with the heart box lid object.

author: mlabruyere

description.text:
The original Secret Heart (44579) was optimised for Makerbot, and just worked, but I had problems printing on anything else. They published the OpenSCAD (thanks), but even after updating for current version and lots of tweaks I had problems, not least of which was that Simplfy3D refused to properly bridge the top unless you make the walls really thick.

I have re-designed this from scratch (twice now), and the OpenSCAD file is included.

The main problem with anything that has moving parts is the clearance tolerance between parts as printed. If that is too small then nothing moves, and if too big then the whole thing is loose. As such I have included STLs for versions with clearance tolerance of 0.2mm, 0.3mm, 0.4mm and 0.5mm. I am using 0.2mm on my TAZ 6.

To save you the hassle of printing the whole thing and finding your have the wrong one, I have also included test prints of key components - the main joint and the hinge for the top flap, each in 0.2mm to 0.5mm clearance tolerance. I suggest printing the main join and seeing if it will turn - you may have to use a knife to separate the two parts slightly to get it to free up.

I have also included an example with lettering, which you can easily make from the OpenSCAD file.

Have fun.

P.S. (12th Feb 16:23) I have been tinkering and re-loading these files a few times...

description.text:

There are two versions of the shell (case) and drawers. It turns out that the stock SeeMeCNC Rostock Max V3 requires a narrow top drawer. So print the part 2DrawerShell-V3-Stock.stl for a stock V3. title: Micro SD card and adapter storage box

description.text:
Micro SD card storage box

No it is not a toaster.
This is a very simple box for storing your micro SD cards that we lose very easily. They can be accompanied by their SD adapter.
And if you are anxious, you can add an elastic to secure the set.
Is not life beautiful?

Update 22/02/2017 : for convenient for everybody, I modified the files with the thickness 1.4mm to 1.6mm to have a multiple of 0.4mm noze : BoiteMicroSD_V02_001aBase.stl and BoiteMicroSD_V02_001aCouv2.stl

Boîte de rangement pour cartes micro SD

Non ce n'est pas un grille pain.
Ce n'est qu'une petite boîte toute simple pour ranger vos cartes micro SD que l'on égare très facilement. Ces petites cartes peuvent être acompagnées de leur adaptateur SD.
Et si vous êtes du genre angoissé, il est même prévu d'y ajouter un élastique afin de sécuriser la fermeture de l'ensemble.
Elle est pas belle la vie ?

Mise à jour du 22/02/2017 : il semblait que certains avaient un petit espace intérieur dans les angles dû à une épaisseur non multiple de 0.4mm (buse classique). J'ai donc modifié les deux fichiers afin d'avoir une épaisseur de 1.6mm : BoiteMicroSD_V02_001aBase.stl et BoiteMicroSD_V02_001aCouv2.stl

description.text:
UPDATE: THE NEW MODULAR VERSION IS HERE!!!
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2720154

UPDATE: CONFIGURATION SETTINGS FOR ANET A8 ADDED (MARLIN) AS REQUESTED. Whole configuration.h file has been added to the files section..

#define X_MIN_POS -15
#define Y_MIN_POS -9
#define Z_MIN_POS 0
#define X_MAX_POS 250
#define Y_MAX_POS 219
#define Z_MAX_POS 240

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -42  // X offset: -left  +right  [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -10  // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0   // Z offset: -below +above  [the nozzle]

  // Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).
  #define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 10
  #define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 205
  #define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 10
  #define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 205

UPDATE: I have added sensor BLTOUCH mounting bracket for this carriage. Check it out! 

UPDATE: I have added inductove sensor mounting bracket for this carriage. Check it out! 

Hi this is a project for anet a8 e3dv6 carriage with full cover

It it a complete carriage solution with base plate, e3dv6 mount, fun ducts and cover with fans.

It can be used with standard lm8uu bearing blocks or with my bearing block solution from my other project that i highly recommend. ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2043585 )

It was tested, fits and works well.

- two fans one for nozzle radiator and second for print coolling
- adjustable ,removable and replaceable fan ducts
- all cables can be fit inside, so it looks clean
- has hole for cable and bowden covering elastic pipe
- easy cover removal for maintenance
- can be used with standard bearing blocks, but recomend mine solution (much much better)

You need:
- print all parts
- two 40mm fans
- e3dV6 (maby other fits? i do not know)
- bearings with blocks
- some m3 screws, and nuts different length
- some m4 screws and nuts to bearing block mount to the plate
- a little soldering skills? (have to replace or extend funs cables)

Note:

please take care about mounting plate scews. There are lots of them in main plate, and some of them are covered by parts mounting later, so before mounting the parts look to place m3 nuts in holes before covering them, becouse there will be no access to them later!!!.

title: Replicator (plus CTC and other Clones) Dual Extruder Level

description.text:
This is a level tool for the dual nozzle Replicator (and clones such as the CTC Bizer).

I didn't want to take my entire print head off of it's carriage to level nozzles. Unlike some of the older printers the nozzles on the CTC are held on by a grub (set) screw and don't require removing the heatsink bar that holds them in place to line them up.

So this is a shorter version of other tools for aligning the nozzles with each other and the carriage. You should be able to press it into place, make sure the nozzles are flush with it, then tighten their setting screw and call it a day. I also put mounting screw holes similar to other tools in case they come in handy on your carriage.

author: Inhibit

description.text:
It looks good but my sorry printer won't print it. Update:

  • I finally printed it. Check out the Instructions up top.
Fact :

Quality printing can be achieved on a cold build platform. This can be done by spraying a light amount of 3M Super 77 onto the removable platform. If it is not removable than you should guard the spray from the smooth rods and electronics. Next the glue needs to dry firmly or at least until you can touch it and nothing sticks to your finger. Now you can print and guess what? Don't turn your heat-bed on, nope don't do it. The cooling fans are not needed too, nor is a brim or a raft. Also once the adhesive is there it will last for several prints before needing more.
But that glue is to strong you say, and indeed it is. You will have to break it off unless...You turn the heatbed on. Yep, just warm it up to around 60 - 70c and you can lift the pieces off and any excess lines with no problem, well maybe a butter knife or something might help. Next you can print again after the bed cools down and you dont need to be very concerned about the tiny lines of plastic as long as they are thin enough to go under the first layer.
The proof that it works is that I finally got printable Segesta to print.
See for yourself.
    • OK, So Maybe I am a bit overzealous indeed the heat-bed is the best way so don't listen to my craziness.

description.text:
Print and play pieces for Santorini. I created these from scratch based on the kickstarter to go with the rest of the print and play cards and board. I took these pieces a step further and created variations of the lvl1 and 2 blocks for a total of 8 different styles of pieces. Fantastic game, lots of fun. I'm currently just using Marvin's for game pieces, the default size is perfect!

Suggest you check it out - https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/roxley/santorini-learn-it-in-30-seconds-play-it-for-life

If there is interest in this I plan on expanding this further with custom pieces and a custom 3d board.

Printer:

Custom Prusai3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Notes:

You can feel free to change the resolution up, but with .2mm layer height total print time was nearly 30 hours for me (I go pretty slow).

For full piece set
Print 7 of each lvl1 variation
Print 6 of each lvl 2 variation
Print 12 Lvl 3 pieces
Print 16 Domes

Supports - Depending on your printer, Lvl1 you don't need any supports. All the other blocks will need a little support around the base to make the lip clean so they fit together. If you can't print the roof without supports you may need it on all of them, I'd suggest calibrating your printer better to allow for better bridging though.

As far as infill goes you shouldn't need much, but its your choice.

author: Laleyenda

description.text:
Here is a simple container that encloses a sliding drawer like a box of matches.  It can be decorated with one of three different repeating patterns.  Two are textile patterns and the third is an array of Pascal triangles.
For monochrome printers the patterns are embossed on the surface and for two color printers the embossed pattern can be in a different color.  Stl files for two versions are provided.  A second textile pattern is included in the zip files.
The patterns were created with openSCAD's polyhedron command which makes them easy to manipulate.
For those who know openSCAD the programs consist of about a dozen lines of code that include a call to a pattern module. Any module that makes a pattern lying on the xy plane can be substituted to make a custom box. The scad files are available in box_scad.zip and the stl files in box_stl.zip.

For dual strusion The stl files occur in pairs which have to be merged and printed. They are:
box_less_textile_1.stl and textile_1.stl
and
box_less_pascal.stl and pascal.stl One drawer fits all boxes - box_drawer.stl For monochrome printers There are two files each of which produces a box with an embossed pattern on the surface. They are:
box_plus_textile_1.stl
and
box_plus_pascal.stl The drawer is again box_drawer.stl One can also get boxes with recessed patterns by printing the basic dual strusion files i.e.
box_less_textile_1.stl
and
box_less_pascal.stl The monochrome files print very well on the Replicator which, at least in my experience, is more accurate than the Thingomatic. Both the embossed and recessed patterns have nice crisp edges. The image at the upper left shows all the versions of the textile pattern and the image at the lower left shows the embossed version of the Pascal triangles.

From Magnus Robot Fighter 4000 A.D. No. 15
Mogul Badur was a evil ruler who had his robot servants kidnap someone every year so he could become young and strong again, for 800 years. these are his robot servants.

Robots are self repairing when damaged, Zyfor was destroyed in a crash before kidnapping Magnus. He is still bent up through out the comic from the crash.

author: janetweber

description.text:
Printable version of a fairchild 22, a two seat touring or training plane, designed in the 1930.
more information on http://www.multec.de

All parts are designed to be printable without support. Dimensions of the model: 27cm of wingspan, length about 19cm.
Height of the highest parts: about 13cm. Make sure to use adhesive tape for holding the parts in place while printing. Some of them have a small base and are high. Print all parts and glue the model together.
Tips for printing:
Some of the parts need no fill. I did the body with perimeter only with good results.
At first glue the wings together (I designed holes in order to make it easier to fit them together and used some 3mm pins to set them in position), then glue the wheels, pay attention to the inner part of each wheel. There is a place for the chassis frame on one part of the wheel.
Next you can glue both chassis parts to the wheels.
Glue the body to the piston (engine of the plane) and stick in both parts of the empenage.
Connecting the wing to the body with the strutting is a bit tricky. I used a wire to connect the strutting to the body (the body has 3 small holes on each side to ensure the correct position of the strutting).
After that glue the chassis to the body. There are slots to show the position of the chassis.
At last you can glue the propeller in place.

But I will upload another version of the wings, cut in 4 parts, hope that works better for your printer.
Another tip: you can cut any stl with netfabb (freeware).

title: Hexagonal Flower Pot (with water level indicator)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a flower (or plant) pot I designed. It has a marking line in case you want to fill the bottom with sand or gravel. Also there is a water level indicator. You can just leave it bare and see the water inside, or you could put a little plastic ball in there to highlight the water level.

For the print I used 105% material flow to ensure the pot won't be leaking anywhere. (The first print had 100% and leaked slowly.)

As a final thought though - I found that the inlet for the water level indicator may clog after some time. So maybe in the future I'll have to make a redesign with a larger inlet hole...

description.text:
My attempt at replicating the HST memorial from photos on the web. I feel like I learned something about Blender by tackling this.

I made one version with a hole in the fist so I could attach it to a wine bottle stopper. I didn't include that in the Blender file, but it does have a model of the front of the "button" that goes in the middle of the fist.

Update 3/1/2017: Added STL of model with button and pre-drilled for use with a wine stopper, I used these. Added photo of somewhat better paint job.

Monoprice Select Mini

Doesn't Matter

Yes

0.175

Infill:

5%

Notes:

The drill hole for the wine stopper was pretty snug on my print, it is supposed to be 8.5mm in diameter. I printed in PLA Plus and was able to make adjustments with a Dremel, but with regular PLA you could probably just carve it out with hand tools as needed.

After reading

Vicki Wenderlich - How To Make A Mushroom

I was pretty sure I could make my way around the Blender interface, and after watching

Darrin Lile - Blender Character Modeling 5 of 10

I had the basic game plan for making my model. Surprisingly reasonable!

Pretty much every technical problem I encountered had already been asked and answered in a Blender forum somewhere.

title: Reset switch for Lee-R's Anet A8 Main Board Cover

description.text:
I made this reset switch to compliment Lee-R's excellent Anet A8 cover. The cover is great (in my opinion) because the holes allow easy mounting of optional extras, like Mosfet switches, etc, without having to re-print another cover.

This switch does NOT require the cover to be removed to install it. Is uses 'barbs/grippers' on the side of the barrel to grip around one of the holes in the cover. Printing just the barrel at 0.2 also allows extra grip as the layers are a little rougher (print the other parts at 0.1).

THE SPRING IS AN OPTIONAL EXTRA. The switch will happily work without it.

If you'd like less switch length, etc. the files are public on 'Onshape', so you can copy and modify it as you'd like. The link is below.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

PLA - Print the main barrel at 0.2, but I suggest that you print everything else at 0.1, so the thread has a chance!

General Notes

The spring is an optional extra. It just gives the button more travel when you press it (although I'm working on a PLA spring). If using a spring, make sure it's quite a soft and loose spring.

Put the plunger in to the main barrel and work back and forth, in various positions, before fully assembling, so loosen them up. They should then move quite freely.

The barrel can be installed in to the cover at various angles, and the plunger can be installed at various 90 degree angles, so, between the two, you should find at least one position where the plunger will happily press the reset switch.

The button top isn't specifically needed either, but will make pressing the plunger much more comfortable.

You may find the threads in the button top and plunger aren't perfect, but they should still fit together very well.

Made with ONSHAPE

I made this using the excellent 'Onshape'. If you'd like to change anything, the onshape files are public, and can be found here:-

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/d5a6f679827839b038fcfb75/w/eb139dc9188be68562567071/e/2825e401db78294cd264f66c

• onshape
  • Parts assembly

title: Double Decker Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a derivative of my Minimal In-line Spinner.
The "Double Decker" is literally just that, the in-line spinner with another "deck" for two more bearings. Not only does this give it a really cool look, but the extra weight gives you extra spin. This also uses the 608 bearings. The included central peg makes for easy finger spinning or place it on a surface, put your finger on top and spin it like a lunatic. There are two different pegs as I printed a couple of differnet designs to see what worked best and these were both winners.

Added files: Double_Decker_R1. I've just knocked the inner corners off the snap pegs to make fitting easier and reduce the risk of breaking them while fitting. I've left the original files for reference.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

You'll need to print with supports for the spinner body and you might want to use a brim on the central peg, depending on your bed adhesion. The higher your infill %, the stronger it will be of course. I'd suggest at least 40% because of the snaps for the outer bearings.

You need to print the body, either of the spinner pegs and two of the peg caps.

Remove support material. Carefully snap on the outer bearings, if you're too rough they might break (yes, I broke my first one)! If you have shielded bearings like the outer ones pictured, you will want to make a small modification to the middle one: Remove the shields, clean the bearing thoroughly and then lube with PTFE spray or similar. There are plenty of online tutorials of how to do this. Fitting of the central peg is self-explanatory.

Pencil Top Fidget Spinner
Minimal Fidget Tri - Spinner
Minimal In-Line Fidget Spinner
Speedy Car Fidget Spinner

These are lead screw brackets for the MakerFarm Pegasus 8" printer.
Much thanks to @jlarsenwy for the design. I had to make some small changes for my recent Pegasus 8", so I've uploaded that and some analysis in case others can make use of it. Please see @jlarsenwy's design for more info.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1989637

1) The extruder motor sticks out far enough that it runs into the left bracket. I had to raise the bracket with an offset block so that the motor goes under it instead of running into it. LeadScrewBracketOffsetBlock has that model.

2) The 25mm-long M5 screws I used had large heads that didn't quite fit inside the recess of the left bracket. So I edited the design and increased the radius by 0.5mm. LeadScrewBracketLeft-5.5mm has that model.

3) On the right side, the end of the bolt that holds the delrin roller to the z axis comes out the front and is in the way of the right bracket. If you turn it around to make room for the bracket, the end then runs into the mounting plate for the electronics in some Z positions. To deal with that I used longer M5 bolts and some nylon lock nuts to mount the electronics away from the Z extrusions. So now the bolt for the delrin roller can be flipped around, making room for the right bracket. I included @jlarsenwy's LeadScrewBracketRight without any changes for completeness.

I went looking for an upgrade because I was getting a lot of ridging in my prints with the stock threaded rods. To confirm the rods were the issue, I used a micrometer to measure the actual Z position across a range of Z travel in increments of 0.1mm. The micrometer only goes down to 0.01mm so I didn't expect it to work well, but the magnitude of the periodic error in the threaded rod was large enough to be quite clear. The period of the error sine is about 0.8mm, which matches the pitch of the rod.
In the chart above, the blue line shows the error on the stock threaded rod while the red line shows the error after the upgrade to a 2mm lead screw.

The image below shows a D12 print before the upgrade (left) and after the upgrade (right) and the difference is pretty clear. The D12 is from here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1043661

comments.text: This is great! I'm glad you were able to modify it for your needs.  I never thought about raising it to give the extruder more clearance on the left.  I just lived with the slight loss of print area, but I also have the 10" and I've switched to the E3D Titan extruder (which I recommend) and that has a smaller footprint.
comments.author: jlarsenwy

comments.text: Thanks again for the design and thanks for the recommendation on the z-axis brace!  While the lead screw was a definite improvement, I'm still struggling to get the print quality up to the same level as my cheap Prusa-i3 clone.

description.text:
The original part was wobbly and not so nice to adjust so I reworked it a bit. Added additional support for the screw to have 2 contact points, a cap and adjusting knob. Works really nice.

For the endstop use the original bracket.

The original part was a great idea just needed a bit of work.

Use M4 threaded rod with two nuts at every end. Or longer screw and hot-push the head of the screw to the cap.

To the adjusting knob at the top I have glued on some paper to know which way to turn.

title: Make #22 - Little Snowy Cabin
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The crunch of snow underfoot, the smell of a log fire, a cosy little lodge in the forest. We wanted to recreate this small slice of winter magic in a print. Faberdashery are releasing daily, seasonal designs for you to print and enjoy. Join in the fun with our 25 Days of Making! This is Make #22 of 25.

Slice with 2 shells (/perimeters) and 5% infill. At coarse resolution (0.3mm), you will find prints have extra shimmer (and print quicker!).
Created in stunning Faberdashery Space Marine PLA^ and Arctic White PLA^ The snowy base requires ~11g of material (~2m of 3mm / ~4m of 1.75mm filament) and the cabin ~15g of material (~2m of 3mm / ~5m of 1.75mm filament) Print the little cabin & snowy base for something to put on the mantlepiece, or the hanging version to put on your tree. Then sit back and indulge in some winter dreaming...

description.text:
V2 of my simple Bow Quiver. All parts exept "unten.stl" are printed with Filaflex. Unten.stl was printed using ABS, but you can also use PLA. Just print all Filaflex parts with at last 50% infill. You also need 2 parts of a 7mm pipe to fasten the quiver on the bowy a log 6mm screw and a nut for the part unten.stl. The length of the screw depends of the with of your limps. I use a piece of a Goldtip Warrior 600 Arrow. Glue the pipe in "kocher" then use "schutz" to hold the quiver on the correct place. Use some strong Rubber Bands to fasten the quiver on the limbs. I use a piece of a bicycle tube. At last you can use "stopfen" to close the pipe on the outside. I filled the quiver with Foam.

Note: For a german speaking people, the "unten.stl" was wrong named. This is the upper part of the quiver :-)

description.text:
https://www.amazon.com/BikeFit-7010102-Bike-Fit-Goniometer/dp/B004WNAI6M/ref=cm_cd_al_qh_dp_t $60 for a piece of plastic with no genuine ingenuity behind it.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Notes:

Set layer height as small as possible to render the graduations as well as possible, & highest resolution.

Scale it until it fits on the bed.

Reference Image BikeFit Goniometer; used this to scale the length

See reference images above. I made cutouts to reduce material & help the user pinpoint the knee joint.

Arbitrary dimensions for the cutouts & sighting guides.

• 4 mm bolt
  • 4 mm locknut/nut
  • 4 mm washer if necessary

Center hole is sized for 4 mm bolt.

Print the same thing twice; a 0th indent is provided & should be visible for most angles. Line this up with the periphery of the one in front.

Add numbers in sharpie yourself. Shaded regions are 35 to 25 deg on the Lemond goniometer.

Note that if you scale the print, which you probably will, the hole in the middle will no longer fit a 4 mm bolt.

• add graduations for measuring handlebars à la BikeFit Goniometer
  • move graduations around as users recommend
  • redesign & optimize for smaller print beds (6" x 6")
  • add numbers
  • forefoot measuring device

Blood Rage was financed with a Kickstarter campaign and their was some "Kickstarter exclusive" mini... along them was the Wolfman, a powerful beast.

This mini is a proxy for all of us that came late to Blood Rage but want to try to play with Wolfman and the other "Kickstarter exclusive".

I am full aware that this mini is at level with the original art (http://www.edgeent.com/sisimg/public/images/blood_rage_ed_ragnarok_product_wolfman.png) but then.... you had to be there on time :p

title: X-Carve 33mm Laser Holder w/ Scope Mount & Safety Panels

description.text:
NOTE: Also have at X-Carve Laser Mount for Opt Lasers PLH3D 6W Laser, this is the newest laser I am using.

Laser Mount for Inventables X-Carve Dewalt Accessory Mount.
For use with lasers modules (33mm x 33mm) like this

Borescope holder is design for 8mm borescope so you can see what you are engraving. I recommend and use this bore scope.

Latest design has a safety panel box that encloses the laser beam and engraving area.
Uses:

  • 4.25mm / 3/16in thick Laser Shielding / High Optical Density Acrylic at OD 4+, cut to size on my x-carve, using Easel
  • 8x 8x1mm magnets, like these
  • super glue for the magnets
  • hot glue to hold the panels into the end caps. (do not glue the panels to each other, there is no need with the end caps installed)
  • 8mm borescope (same as standard mount)

Be sure you use SAFETY GLASSES

As an additional note:
If you like using Inventables Easel, check out my simple JavaScript app "gcode-depths-to-shades" that will converts 3-Axis CNC Router G-code generated from applications such as Easel, and turn it into G-code suitable for 2-Axis CNC Laser Engraving.

Designed in Onshape

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/e11a40ccfc70e0eb3175e3fd/w/851a67df82d06d6769a54480/e/1f19577e500e877416dcade4

title: Turbine Blower, housing, and motor electric motor mount.

description.text:
Update: Added Motor_Plate_12-19-13.stp, Motor_Plate_12-19-13.igs, Turbine_12-19-13.stp and Turbine_12-19-13.igs. I've had requests to add solid files for the motor mounting plate so people could modify it to fit their specific motor. This turbine blower assembly was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39755. I had some problems finding the right motor/gear combination so I modified the turbine so that it could fit a common 9-18V electric motor. I believe I used a Radio Shack# 273-256 The upper housing has added support in the output tube that can easily be cut out. 3/24/14 - Added solid models! Enjoy! The hardware required is: 7 M3-.5X10mm Socket cap screws.
7 M3-.5 Nylon Lock Nuts
14 M3 Flat Washers and 2 screws for the motor. I don't know the exact size. I couldn't find them at the Home Depot. I robbed them from a junk laptop I had in my basement. (Possibly M2 or M2.5?) Enjoy!
